M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting matters concerning Sophie pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, M.G.L. c. 209B, as well as the federal Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act (28 U.S.C. § 1738A), because Massachusetts is and has been the child’s home state.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting matters concerning Sophie pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, M.G.L. c. 209B, as well as the federal Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act (28 U.S.C. § 1738A), because Massachusetts is and has been the child’s home state.

Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction.raw_text: Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, M.G.L. c. 209B
Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting matters concerning Sophie pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, M.G.L. c. 209B, as well as the federal Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act (28 U.S.C. § 1738A), because Massachusetts is and has been the child’s home state.

28 U.S.C. \u00a7 1738A.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting matters concerning Sophie pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28; M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, M.G.L. c. 209B, as well as the federal Parental Kidnapping Prevention Act (28 U.S.C. § 1738A), because Massachusetts is and has been the child’s home state.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: In Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996), the Supreme Judicial Court held that the Probate and Family Court may modify custody or parenting time when a material change of circumstances has occurred since the prior order and where modification is necessary to serve the child’s best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion is an appeal from an initial custody judgment, not a modification proceeding, and the court does not discuss or apply a "material change of circumstances" standard for altering an existing custody or parenting time order. The SJC instead addresses the need for explicit findings on domestic violence and its effect on the child in making a custody determination. Therefore, Custody of Vaughn does not stand for the general proposition that the Probate and Family Court may modify custody or parenting time upon a material change of circumstances and where modification serves the child’s best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above."

Silvia v. Silvia, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 339,.raw_text: Silvia v. Silvia, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 339, 342 (1980)
Silvia v. Silvia, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 339,.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently emphasize that the “paramount concern” in custody and parenting matters is the best interests of the child.
Silvia v. Silvia, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 339,.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on interpreting G.L. c. 208, § 28 as imposing a gender‑neutral duty of child support and on what financial circumstances (including those of each parent and a second spouse) may be considered. While the statute quoted mentions acting for the “benefit of the children,” the court does not discuss or emphasize the broader best-interests/paramount-concern standard in custody or parenting matters, nor does it frame its analysis in those terms. Thus the case does not meaningfully support the specific proposition cited.
Silvia v. Silvia, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 339,.relevant_excerpt: “[T]he court may make such judgment as it considers expedient relative to the care, custody and maintenance of the minor children of the parties, and may determine with which of the parents the children or any of them shall remain, or may award their custody to some third person if it seems expedient or for the benefit of the children; and afterward may from time to time…revise and alter such judgment or make a new judgment, as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 402–03 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently emphasize that the “paramount concern” in custody and parenting matters is the best interests of the child.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states that in deciding custody issues, the “overriding concern” must be the promotion of the children’s best interests and welfare, and it cites multiple Massachusetts cases reaffirming this principle. While it does not use the exact phrase “paramount concern,” its language and citations clearly affirm that the best interests of the child control custody determinations in Massachusetts, consistent with the proposition.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930). Heard v. Heard, 323 Mass. 357, 375-377 (1948). Clifford v. Clifford, 354 Mass. 545, 548 (1968) (‘sole question’ is what is best for children’s welfare).”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently emphasize that the “paramount concern” in custody and parenting matters is the best interests of the child.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the removal decision in terms of the children’s “best interests” and interprets the governing statute (G.L. c. 208, § 30) to permit removal only if it is in the child’s best interests. The court criticizes the trial judge for using too narrow a focus and explains that all relevant factors must be weighed to determine what arrangement best serves the children, confirming that the paramount concern in this custody/parenting context is the children’s best interests.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt:
The words “upon cause shown” in the controlling statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30, set forth in the margin, have been interpreted to permit removal if in the best interests of the child. Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). However, the criteria for determining such best interests have, as yet, not been established, and decisions of the trial court as to whether removal should be allowed have been upheld without much discussion.
...
We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: In determining best interests and whether modification is appropriate, the Court considers, among other factors, the child’s emotional and physical needs, stability and continuity of care, the effect of changes in residence or schooling, and the impact of parental decisions on the child’s daily life.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes what must be considered in determining the child’s best interests in a removal/custody context. The court identifies evaluation of the effect of removal on the child, including improvement in quality of life, the impact of changes on emotional, physical, and developmental needs, and the curtailment of association with the noncustodial parent—concepts that encompass emotional and physical needs, stability/continuity, changes in residence/schooling, and impact on daily life. Thus it supports the proposition as to factors relevant to best interests and modification/removal decisions.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.” (395 Mass. at 710–11).

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.proposition: In determining best interests and whether modification is appropriate, the Court considers, among other factors, the child’s emotional and physical needs, stability and continuity of care, the effect of changes in residence or schooling, and the impact of parental decisions on the child’s daily life.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that a best-interests determination is “grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child” and then applies that standard by weighing the child’s educational and special needs, the quality of current schooling, the disruption and “uprooting” caused by a move, and the reduction in parenting time and daily involvement of the father. These are the same types of factors described in the proposition: emotional/physical needs, stability and continuity of care, effects of changes in residence or schooling, and the impact of parental decisions on the child’s daily life. The court’s analysis of whether modification/removal is appropriate is framed in precisely these terms.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 184\u20.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move. She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests, that potential misconduct by other siblings in the mother’s household weighed against increased physical custody by the mother, and that any financial or other advantage of the move to the mother was unclear.”

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: In determining best interests and whether modification is appropriate, the Court considers, among other factors, the child’s emotional and physical needs, stability and continuity of care, the effect of changes in residence or schooling, and the impact of parental decisions on the child’s daily life.

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: In Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015), the Appeals Court acknowledged that a material change may arise when post‑judgment developments—such as relocation or shifts in logistical realities—render the existing parenting plan impracticable or inconsistent with the child’s best interests.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal and child‑support modification case, not a general parenting‑plan modification case based on post‑judgment logistical changes. The Appeals Court analyzes the mother’s request to relocate under the Yannas ‘real advantage’/best‑interests framework and the father’s child‑support modification based on her remarriage; it does not discuss or acknowledge that a material change can arise when later logistical developments make an existing parenting plan impracticable or inconsistent with the child’s best interests. The claimed proposition therefore overreads the case and is not grounded in its reasoning or holding.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “The mother, Dawn Michelle Murray, appeals from a judgment of the Probate and Family Court dismissing her complaint for modification, which sought to remove the minor children of the marriage to the State of California. Where the parent seeking to move has primary physical custody of the children, the standard governing removal of the minor children from the Commonwealth requires a determination whether there is a real advantage to the custodial parent and consideration of the best interests of the children and the interests of both parents.”

Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.raw_text: Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 908 (2005)
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that repeated, lengthy travel and disruption of a child’s routine can be detrimental, and that parenting plans must be tailored to the child’s age, schooling, and developmental needs.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.case_name: Massachusetts Correction Officers Federated Union v. Commissioner of Correction
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a labor arbitration enforcement dispute between a correction officers’ union and the Department of Correction. It does not involve family law, parenting plans, child custody, or any discussion of children’s travel, routines, schooling, or developmental needs. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about tailoring parenting plans to a child’s circumstances.
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: The union does not allege a new violation of the collective bargaining agreement requiring resolution by the grievance procedure and arbitration. At issue here is nothing more than the enforcement of the underlying arbitration award, warranting its confirmation in a judgment of the court.

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that repeated, lengthy travel and disruption of a child’s routine can be detrimental, and that parenting plans must be tailored to the child’s age, schooling, and developmental needs.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the governing standard of the child’s welfare and the need for findings on comparative parental environments. It does not discuss repeated or lengthy travel, disruption of the child’s routine, or how parenting plans should be tailored to age, schooling, or developmental needs. The case is about requiring proper best-interest findings in a custody determination, not about the specific travel- and routine-related concerns described in the proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments. Findings also would be appropriate concerning (1) the length of time the child has been in her present environment and under the primary care of her father at his home and (2) whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being.”
